repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Financial Sector Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated marginally
            unsatisfactory with respect to the development objective of
            strengthening institutions in the financial sector so that
            financial services could be provided in an efficient and
            effective manner. Project sustainability is assessed as
            likely, but the report cautions it would be prudent to wait
            another eighteen months before an impact evaluation can be
            carried out since a number of project activities suffered
            implementation delays and the impact of their implementation
            is yet to register. Overall world Bank performance is rated
            unsatisfactory, although this is on the thin borderline
            between "marginally satisfactory" and
            "unsatisfactory." Overall borrower performance is
            unsatisfactory: while the borrower remained committed to the
            project's objectives and was engaged in continuous
            dialogue with the Bank on policy issues, there were
            instances where information affecting the financial sector
            reform program was not freely shared with the Bank. The
            Borrower also did little to solve the problems causing
            delays in implementation progress. The implementation agency
            's performance was largely responsible for the delays
            in some components. Som of the lessons learned from this
            project include: More attention should be paid to the
            quality of privatizations of state-owned banks. The removal
            of political influence in the bank's day-to-day
            operations should be a top priority during privatization.

18156761.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rule of law,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Financial Sector Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Capacity Building
            (FS CB) project will develop and strengthen the institutions
            charged with implementing the policy and institutional
            reforms agreed under the Second Economic Recovery Credit
            (SERC). The project will: (a) train central bank staff so
            that they can undertake - better macro-monetary management,
            prudential supervision of the financial sector, and manage a
            more effective system of foreign exchange allocation; (b)
            train staff in the commercial banks so that they can more
            effectively provide trade finance to importers, appraise
            credit applications and, for higher level staff in the
            banks, provide more effective overall management; (c) train
            a core of legal professionals in the central bank and the
            Ministry of Finance to review and re-draft financial and
            other related legislation for its applicability in a
            deregulated financial environment - and to also strengthen
            legal systems which may beneficially impact upon the overall
            operation of the financial system; (d) support institution
            building within the financial sector, through the
            recruitment of technical assistance experts who can, in
            large part, train local staff and help develop local
            competencies; and (e) study certain aspects of the financial
            sector in great depth, to provide a better understanding of
            possible policy alternatives.
